body.p:
Yrs yours of the 8th recd. received Yes; I rec'd received Knortz's
pam. pamphlet in same mail with yr your letter. I have read it & find it good—comprehensive, scholarly, & fair. I wd would not want a better or more complete introduction to the whole German nation than that contained in his pamphlet. I see no trace of clericalism in it. He devotes five pages to an earnest & unqualified defense of Children of Adam though as he says, you do "smoke pretty strong tobacco" [!] in those poems. He finds "Out of the Cradle Endlessly Rocking" the finest, tenderest & most soul mastering Bird— idyl idyll in the whole literature of the world. He covers the whole ground (hastily) without however, rising ever into any very profound or original thought.
Did you find that letter of Rhys's? I will gladly accept yr your suggestion as to title "Walt Whitman" &c

I shd should like very much to have something about Scovel to put in if anybody cd could give me a few data. He has been such a good friend. I know Donaldson so little that I hardly know whether to clan him with Burroughs & O'Connor or not: I hardly dare to state here on paper the uncertainties I feel about him. You see how that I have written about him strikes you when you come to read the MS. I may omit it altogether.

I have preluded & bragged so much (as is my naïve way) that I guess I'd better give you now a hint as to the "spine" of my book. It is a good deal of a melange; but I believe the back-bone idea of it lies in the word "apotheosis."

list.item: III The Style of Leaves of Grass
IV Analytical Introduction To Leaves of Grass
VII Walt Whitman and His Friends

body.p: The first three chapters attempt to once & for all set at rest the uncertainty as to the purity & supreme worth of Leaves of Grass, & the greatness of W. W. as a man & author. They form a tremendous eulogium, & seem to me to be exhaustive & unanswerable.
The next three chapters are interpretative & analytical chiefly.
But I must stop & get to work on it. For serious interruptions are looming up in the near future. A publisher buttonholed me in Boston yesterday.
One of these scorcher days nearly used me up. Glad you are well as usual. Thanks for yr your news abt about J.B. & Dr. B.
Edwd Edward Carpenter has sent me a really fine article of his on Simplification of Life. I know it is his by the style.
